Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploration of Infrared-excited Quantum Dots and Quantum Dots with built-in Spontaneous Polarizations in Switching Transmembrane Ion Channels

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will explore the use of quantum dots with built-in spontaneous polarizations and infrared-excited quantum dots in switching voltage-gated ion channels. Specifically, this project will study the interaction of the dipole fields produced by the built-in spontaneous polarization as well as by the radiation-induced polarization of quantum dots with ion channels that are gated with voltages. This research will include STM/AFM characterization of semiconductor quantum dots under illumination and of semiconductor quantum dots that have built-in spontaneous polarizations in the absence of external radiation; results will be compared with modeled characteristics. Patch clamp techniques will be used to measure the response of voltage-gated ion channels to these quantum-dot fields for a variety of scenarios including: (A) the switching of ion channels with infrared-excited quantum dots that are bound directly to ion channels with molecular linkers, and (B) the switching of ion channels for the case where quantum dots having large built-in spontaneous polarizations, that produce large electric fields surrounding the quantum dots, are bound directly to ion channels by molecular linkers. This project will conduct proof-of-principle research underlying the excitation of quantum dots with tissue-penetrating infrared radiation for the subsequent active control of ion channels as well as the static gating of ion channels using quantum dots that have built-in spontaneous polarizations in the absence of external illumination.

Broader Impact: The broader impacts of this program are numerous and they underlie the exploitation of novel nanosystems that will perform functions - not now performed with current devices and systems that will have impact on economic, medical, and scientific issues, as well as the education of new generations of students in emerging techniques that will have broad and continuing payoffs in a variety of scientific, medical, technological, and economic applications. In particular, this project underlies the novel use manmade colloidal quantum-dot nanosystems consisting of semiconductor colloidal quantum dots to influence the functions of biological ion channels. The success of this program would advance the application of nanotechnology to the beneficial control and modification of ion channel functions. As specific examples of impact, this program will explore novel approaches for using colloidal quantum dots for switching ion channels that have potential for long-term practical applications including: (A) the control of neural functions and response; (B) advanced prosthetics and; (C) the design of novel manmade nanostructures that perform channel blocking functions similar to those of many drugs employed in the neurological and cardiac applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes Report

 

This EAGER project had the goal of exploring the use of manmade nanostructures surrounded by electric fields with biological ion channels.  These ion channels are essential in controlling the flow of ions between the extracellular region and the cytoplasm.  The flow of these ions plays the critical role of producing action potentials that act as the signals transmitted in neurons.  These neuronal action potential are responsible for the transmission of signal in the body.  Ion channels can be opened or closed through a process known as gating.  Among the various types of ion channels, gating is caused by mechanical, chemical, or voltage induced effects.  The ion channels studied in this research are voltage-gated ion channels and they can be opened or closed – switched – by exposing the ion channel to a voltage difference caused by an electric field.  In this research, the voltage gating of ion channels was studied by exposing these ion channels to manmade nanostructures with surrounding electric fields.  Specifically, these nanostructures are manmade quantum dots with surrounding dipolar electric fields.  This EAGER project explored the use of semiconductor quantum dots with surrounding dipolar electric fields in switching voltage-gated ion channels.  Specifically, this project examined the interaction of the dipole fields of these quantum dots with voltage-gated biological ion channels.   This research employed electrostatic force microscopy (EFM) –-- a variety of atomic force microscopy (AFM) and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) --- as well as transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to characterize the dipole fields surrounding these nanoscale quantum dots as well as their morphology.  Furthermore, patch clamp techniques were used to measure the response of voltage-gated ion channels to these quantum-dot fields for the case where UV-excited quantum dots are in suspension in the electrolyte of the extracellular medium.  In parallel, with these experimental measurements, theoretical models were formulated to model the effect of manmade nanostructures with surrounding electric fields.  Using these techniques, the influence of the electric fields of manmade quantum on the ionic currents transmitted through ion channels were measured and modeled.  In particular, the effect of the electric fields of these quantum dots induced by illumination of the quantum dots was studied for voltage-gated ion channels in horizontal cells.  Further studies and extensions of this research portend applications such as the suppression, enhancement, and control of neuronal signals in biological systems.  It is possible that extensions of this research could open avenues to the control of neurological disorders.
